metadata.titleEn: Inventory of glacial lakes in the Poqui Basin, Central Himalaya (1964-2017)
metadata.description: The data files include the extent of the Poqui watershed and multiple periods of glacial lake cataloguing. The  glacial lake extent in 1964, was obtained using manual outlining methods based on geo-corrected KH-4 data; the glacial lake extent during 1976-2017, based on Landsat MSS/TM/ETM+/OLI imagery, used a semi-automatic water body classification method to distinguish between water body and non-water body information, and then extracted lake boundaries, and visually checked and manually edited by comparison with the original Landsat images.The relationship between glacial meltwater and glacial lake recharge was determined from RGI 6.0 glacier catalogues and Google Earth.
metadata.instructions: The glacial lake catalogues are named according to the date (YYYY/MM/DD) of the image source data and can be used with software such as QGIS or ArcGIS.

authorList.unitEn: Institute of Tibetan Plateau Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the data collection methods used for cataloging ice lakes in the central Himalayas from 1964 to 2017?
Feature Specification.Answer: manual and semi-automated techniques, manually delineated boundaries, geometrically corrected KH-4 data, Landsat MSS/TM/ETM+/OLI imagery, semi-automated water body classification, lake boundary extraction, visual inspection, manual editing, RGI6.0 glacier inventory, Google Earth

Definition.Question: What does 'semi-automatic water classification method' mean in the context of identifying water bodies in remote sensing data?
Definition.Answer: The 'semi-automatic water classification method' refers to a data collection technique used to differentiate water bodies from non-water bodies in remote sensing data, specifically within Landsat MSS/TM/ETM+/OLI imagery. This method involves automated processes to classify water features, followed by visual inspection and manual editing to ensure accuracy in delineating lake boundaries.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects on data accuracy when using semi-automated water body classification methods compared to manual digitization in ice lake mapping?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using semi-automated water body classification methods, based on Landsat MSS/TM/ETM+/OLI imagery, can lead to improved efficiency and consistency in identifying water bodies compared to manual digitization. However, it may also introduce errors due to the limitations of automated processes in distinguishing between water and non-water features, which necessitates visual inspection and manual editing for accuracy. The reliance on different satellite data over time might also affect consistency and precision, as each sensor has varying resolution and spectral capabilities.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can one implement a semi-automatic water body classification method to distinguish water and non-water information from Landsat imagery in the context of ice lake cataloging?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: A semi-automatic water body classification method involves using Landsat MSS/TM/ETM+/OLI imagery to differentiate between water and non-water areas. This is achieved by initially applying a classification algorithm to identify water bodies and then extracting the lake boundaries. The results are visually inspected and manually edited by comparing them with the original Landsat images to ensure accuracy and precision in ice lake cataloging.
